Things I Use

I love tools, and I wish everyone would include a page like this on their website. Futzing with tools is often a waste of time, but once in a while you find one that’s legitimately game-changing (Anki, for instance). I pretty much live for that.

Writing

At the moment, I’m writing everything in VS Code. There are some advantages to doing so which maybe I’ll write about someday.

Enso comes in handy for distraction-free word-dumping. I’d use beat if I still wrote screenplays, except maybe not, because VS Code also has a very good fountain plugin.

Dictionaries

In order of consultation.

  • The New Oxford American Dictionary (macOS)
  • Merriam-Webster
  • The Free Dictionary
  • The Oxford Dictionary of English (British English, macOS)

Thesauruses

  • Thesaurus.com
  • Roget’s Thesaurus

Use less, but not useless

  • Online Etymology Dictionary
  • Webster’s 1913 Dictionary (macOS)

Reading

I track feeds and read articles with Readwise.

For books, I have a Kindle and library card. The Internet Archive often comes in handy. I recently switched from Goodreads to LibraryThing because Goodreads is sluggish and I hate it. LibraryThing, by contrast, is faster, might be open source (I’m not sure, but it has the feel of it), and overall is kind of cool.

Notetaking

I manage notes and files with VS Code. I used to use Obsidian, which is excellent software, but there wasn’t anything I was doing with it that I couldn’t do as well or better with VS Code.

I annotate articles and ebooks with Readwise. All notes I take in Readwise, on my Kindle, or in iBooks show up in my Readwise database. I used to export that database to Obsidian but now I send them to Google Drive.

For memorizing facts, quotes, and other information, I use spaced repetition via Anki.

Webdev

I code in VS Code. I use GitHub for version control. I use Firefox Developer Edition for development. I design in Figma. I built this website with Astro.

Other

  • Browser: Vivaldi
  • Terminal: iTerm2

I built this website with Astro. You can see the source on GitHub.
